name: Bangladesh
currentCrisisSummary:
Bangladesh hosts the world's largest and most densely populated refugee settlement, a direct consequence of a campaign of ethnic cleansing and plausible genocide committed by the neighbouring state of Myanmar. Over one million Rohingya, a stateless Muslim minority, live in precarious, sprawling camps in Cox's Bazar after being violently driven from their ancestral lands.

The crisis within Bangladesh is one of protracted displacement, acute humanitarian need, and suspended rights. The refugees face severe overcrowding, limited access to formal education and livelihoods, and high vulnerability to climate shocks like cyclones and floodingâ€”a direct consequence of the imperial legacy of global industrialisation. While Bangladesh, a nation grappling with its own pressures within a neoliberal global economy, bears the immense logistical and financial burden, the crisis's root causes lie entirely within Myanmar's long history of state-sponsored persecution. The international community's failure to hold Myanmar accountable, combined with geopolitical interests that shield the regime, has created a stalemate, trapping the Rohingya in indefinite exile.

colonialRoot.legacy:
The Rohingya's statelessness is a direct legacy of British colonial policy in Burma. During their rule, the British administered Burma as a province of India and encouraged the migration of labourers, including many Rohingya, from the Bengal region into Arakan (now Rakhine State) to work on agricultural projects. This movement was fluid, across a border that was a colonial imposition.

After Burma's independence in 1948, the new state's nationalist project sought to define a pure 'Burmese' identity. The Rohingya, with their different ethnicity, religion, and colonial-era migration history, were framed as foreign interlopers and 'illegal Bengali migrants'. British 'divide and rule' tactics, which pitted ethnic groups against each other, created the post-colonial resentments that the Myanmar state later weaponised to strip the Rohingya of their identity and citizenship.

historicalContext.title: State-Sponsored Persecution and Statelessness
historicalContext.description: The post-colonial Burmese state institutionalised discrimination against the Rohingya. This culminated in the 1982 Citizenship Law, a piece of legislation designed to legally erase the Rohingya's existence. By refusing to recognise them as one of the country's official ethnic groups, the law rendered them stateless in their own homeland. This act of legal violence stripped them of all fundamental rightsâ€”to vote, to travel, to own land, to access educationâ€”and formalised their status as a people to be persecuted with impunity.

historicalContext.title: Ethnic Cleansing and Genocidal Violence
historicalContext.description: The decades of discrimination erupted into systematic, state-directed violence. In 2017, the Myanmar military (the Tatmadaw) launched so-called 'clearance operations' in response to militant attacks. This was a cover for a premeditated and brutal campaign of mass killing, gang rape, and the razing of hundreds of villages. The intent was to terrorise the Rohingya population into fleeing en masse. This violent expulsion, which drove over 750,000 people into Bangladesh in a few months, is now the subject of a genocide case at the International Court of Justice.

historicalContext.title: Geopolitical Indifference and Impunity
historicalContext.description: Myanmar's military regime has been shielded from meaningful international accountability. China and Russia, citing the principle of non-interference, have used their UN Security Council vetoes to block strong action, protecting their own strategic and economic investments in Myanmar, including projects in Rakhine State itself. Western nations have imposed sanctions but have failed to apply sufficient pressure to alter the regime's behaviour. Regional bodies like ASEAN have adhered to a policy of non-confrontation, effectively normalising the crime and leaving Bangladesh to manage the humanitarian fallout alone.

historicalContext.title: Humanitarian Response and Neoliberal Governance
historicalContext.description: The international response in Cox's Bazar, while essential, operates within a neoliberal framework. It is a multi-billion dollar aid industry dominated by large international organisations that can sideline local capacity. This model creates a parallel economy and a system of 'governance-by-aid' that manages the crisis in a state of permanent emergency without addressing the political or economic root causes, while placing immense strain on the host nation's own development.

historicalContext.title: International Law And Accountability
historicalContext.description: Formal accountability efforts are underway but face significant political obstacles. The Gambia, on behalf of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation, has brought a case against Myanmar at the International Court of Justice, accusing it of violating the Genocide Convention. The International Criminal Court has also opened an investigation. These legal processes are vital for documenting the atrocities and challenging state impunity, but their ultimate effectiveness is contingent on the political will of powerful nations to enforce their rulings.

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 1 million Rohingya refugees are hosted in Bangladesh, the vast majority having fled since August 2017.

humanitarianImpact.title: Displaced
humanitarianImpact.description: Virtually the entire Rohingya population of northern Rakhine State was forcibly displaced from Myanmar.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: An estimated 24,000 Rohingya were killed during the 2017 military operations, with thousands more subjected to sexual violence.

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected
humanitarianImpact.description: The entire refugee population in Bangladesh lives in complete dependency on humanitarian aid.

humanitarianImpact.title: Children Out of School
humanitarianImpact.description: Over half a million refugee children have been denied access to formal, accredited education, creating a 'lost generation'.

humanitarianImpact.title: Lack of Rights and Livelihoods
humanitarianImpact.description: As stateless refugees, the Rohingya are not permitted to work legally or travel freely in Bangladesh, leaving them without prospects for self-sufficiency.

humanitarianImpact.title: Climate Vulnerability
humanitarianImpact.description: The mega-camps are built on fragile, flood-prone land, making the stateless Rohingya population exceptionally vulnerable to the cyclones and monsoon flooding that are intensifying due to the climate crisis.

timeline.event: **British Annexation**: The British Empire annexes Arakan and begins to encourage labour migration from the Bengal region to work in rice paddies, laying the demographic groundwork for future conflict.
**Burmese Independence**: Burma becomes independent from Britain. The new state begins to build a national identity that increasingly excludes the Rohingya.
**Citizenship Law**: Myanmar's military government enacts a new citizenship law that intentionally omits the Rohingya from the list of recognised ethnic groups, formally rendering them stateless.
**Sectarian Violence**: A major outbreak of organised violence in Rakhine State kills hundreds of Rohingya and displaces over 140,000 into squalid internal displacement camps.

**Genocidal 'Clearance Operations'**: The Myanmar military launches a massive, systematic campaign of violence. Over 750,000 Rohingya flee to Bangladesh in a matter of weeks, in one of the fastest forced migrations in recent history.

**International Court of Justice Genocide Case**: The Gambia files a case against Myanmar at the International Court of Justice, formally accusing the state of committing genocide against the Rohingya.
**Myanmar Coup**: The Myanmar military seizes full power in a coup, shattering any remaining hopes for a democratic path to safe and dignified repatriation for the Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh.

donate.description: Provides emergency aid, including food, water, and shelter, to Rohingya refugees fleeing persecution.
Provides protection, shelter and essential services to Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh and to other displaced populations in the region.

advocacy: Support the genocide case against Myanmar at the International Court of Justice and demand that your government formally backs the case.
Advocate for targeted sanctions against Myanmar's military leaders and the business enterprises that fund their regime.
Oppose any plans for the premature or forced repatriation of Rohingya refugees to Myanmar until their citizenship, safety, and rights are guaranteed.
Demand that the government of Bangladesh provides formal education and livelihood opportunities for refugees to ensure dignity and prevent a lost generation.
Amplify Rohingya voices and support Rohingya-led organisations advocating for their own rights and future.

reading.title: The Rohingyas: Inside Myanmar's Hidden Genocide
reading.description: Azeem Ibrahim provides a concise and powerful account of the long history of persecution leading up to the 2017 atrocities.

reading.title: First, They Erased Our Name: A Rohingya Speaks
reading.description: A personal memoir by Habiburahman that provides a powerful, first-hand account of the lived experience of persecution and statelessness as a Rohingya in Myanmar.

reading.title: Burma's Spring: A Survey of the New Landscape
reading.description: While broader than just the Rohingya, this collection of essays provides critical analysis of the political and economic transitions in Myanmar that created the context for the 2017 violence.
